data.title: Finland
data.meta_description: From the point of view of strategic culture, Finland is most often analyzed as a country that is institutionally a member of the EU (since 1995) but not of NATO. Moreover, national defense still plays a pivotal role in the construction of Finnish nationhood. The...
data.text: From the point of view of strategic culture, Finland is most often analyzed as a country that is institutionally a member of the EU (since 1995) but not of NATO. Moreover, national defense still plays a pivotal role in the construction of Finnish nationhood. The legacy of the Second World War, especially the myth of the heroic fight against the Soviet Union in 1939â€“1940, has given national self-defense a positive aura. Arguably, this historical experience has also shaped present-day perceptions on why Finland needs armed forces, how they should be organized and when and how they should be used.
